hints.content: Start by breaking down both sentences into lists of words. This will allow you to easily compare the words in both sentences and identify where they match or differ.

Consider the possibility of matching the beginning and end of both sentences. If the start of one sentence matches the start of the other, and the end matches as well, there might be a middle part that can be inserted.
Think about how to handle cases where one sentence is significantly shorter than the other. If one sentence has fewer words, it might be easier to visualize inserting words into the longer sentence.
When comparing the two lists of words, focus on the longest common prefix and suffix. This could help you determine if the sentences can be made similar by inserting words in between.
You can use two pointers to traverse both lists of words. Start from the beginning of both lists and move forward until the words no longer match.
After finding the matching prefix, do the same from the end of both lists to find the matching suffix. This will help you identify the middle part that needs to be inserted.
If you have matched all words from one of the sentences, the other sentence must only contain the matching prefix and suffix, with the middle part being the additional words.
Consider edge cases such as when one or both sentences are empty. An empty sentence can be considered a valid insert between two words.
Ensure that you handle cases where the sentences are identical or one is a complete subset of the other. Both should return true.
Finally, think about how you will return the result. You need to return true if the sentences can be made similar and false otherwise. Ensure your logic accounts for all possible configurations.

questionNotes: Sentences consist of lowercase and uppercase English letters and spaces.
Words are separated by a single space with no leading or trailing spaces.
